course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Electronic and Information Technology
course.description: This general-education course introduces the basics of electronic and information technology and their applications to daily-life consumer electronics and communication devices. Contents include the representation of signals in the time and frequency domains; digitization of information; coding for data compression and error protection; transmission of signals; cellular mobile phones and wireless communications; and the Internet. It is expected that through studying these technologies and how they address the problems encountered in the information technology area, students will also grasp the skills in solving problems with engineering approach and spirit and appreciate how these technologies impact the society.

reviews.author: polar
reviews.title: Think twice before you take this course.
reviews.comment_content:
Course Outline:
Chapter 1: Signals and Systems
Chapter 2: Digital Systems
Chapter 3: Digitization
Chapter 4: Coding of Digital Information
Chapter 5: Communications
Chapter 6: The Internet

It's a great introductory CC course to learn related topics if you have no prior knowledge. Nevertheless, due to this course's popularity, you probably can only enrol this course in your senior year. When you finally enrolled, your classmate will likely be a year 4 Engineering student who has already learnt 75% of the course and just wants to fulfil the SSC-S&T CC requirement.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Another semester with online lectures via Zoom ğŸ™‚.

I didn't attend many lectures. The professor mostly read from the slides.

Tang Tang is a great tutor who can explain concepts clearly. I recommend you to attend the tutorial if you decide to take this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
Homework: 10% (2% each)
Midterm (Online): 45%
Final Exam (Online): 45%

There is an optional group project with 2 people in a group create a ppt introducing a technology. If your group get 8/10 or above, your final grade will be one sub-grade up. I didn't do the optional project but seems many students said it's difficult to get 8/10 or above.

---

Tl;dr: If you are good at high school Maths and Physics, you can have a good grade with little effort. Otherwise, go find another course.

From the grading scheme, you can notice that this course's grading heavily depends on your exam performance. Both midterm and final exam are MC questions on Canvas. Once you have answered a question, you can't go back.  You are required to turn on the camera on your phone to clearly see your face, your hand, and your computer's monitor to prevent cheating. You have 50 minutes to answer 30 MC questions in the midterm exam; and 35 questions in the final. The time is limited and you can't double-check your answers.

If you want to take this course since it is one of the "good grade courses", then you have to consider the following questions:
- Are you already familiar with some of the topics covered in this course? For example, you are a EE/ CPEG student, or you have learnt Physics in high school.
- Are you good at Maths/ Physics so that you can calculate your answer quickly and accurately in the exam?

If both of your answers are "No", you'd better choose another course to fulfil your common core requirement. I am neither familiar with the course topics nor good at Maths and Physics. I got a bad result in both exams so my grade sucks too. That's fair, but I'd rather take another course.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is small, only 5 homework which can be finished within 2 hours. Most homework problems are taught in tutorials so make sure to check the tutorial notes.
I'm not sure about the workload of the project.
There is no attendance.

However, you need to spend extra time to revise the material before the exam if it is the first time you encounter these topics. Remember, many of your classmates are Year 3/4 Engineering students who know Maths and Physics.

reviews.author: Kikiwithcat
reviews.title: ELEC 1010 - A common core for non-engineering background student
reviews.comment_content:
Topics:
-Introduction to Signals and Systems
-Sound Signal, Frequency and Harmonics
-Signals as Sum of Sine Waves
-Spectrum â€“ Representation of Signals in the Frequency Domain
-Systems as Filters of Signals
-Frequency Translation
-Benefits of Digitization
-Logic with Bits and Bytes
-Introduction to Analog to Digital Conversion  
-Quantization
-Claude Shannon and Information Theory
-Introduction to Source Coding
-Huffman Code and MPEG
-Error Detecting Codes
-Error Correcting Codes
-Channel Capacity  
-Introduction to Wireless Communications    
-Cellular Network Basics
-Multiple Access Technologies
-Nuts and bolts view of the Internet
-Content Distribution Networks & Peer-to-Peer Networks

Some of the topics are covered in HKDSE ICT & Physics so many people will skip the class and watch lecture video before doing HW & exams.

Some tips for exam:
- Try your best to do as fast as possible in mid term
- You might not have enough time to finish every questions so select questions that you are familiar to work with
- Try to write some steps when doing calculations (step marks counts!)
reviews.comment_teaching:
This course has lecture video !

In terms of  9:00 am class, professor really tried his best to start the class on time and make the content interesting to us. He tried to speak of some common / daily examples about the technology in almost every course chapter to arouse our interest in ELEC.

Cupid is very helpful and she replies email very quickly. I didn't study physics in high school so it is quite difficult for me to understand sound waves (in the first chapter). She is very patient when I ask her some silly questions (which is like common sense to engineering students).
reviews.comment_grading:
5 Homework in total, each cost 2% (10%)
Mid Term (35%)
Final (55%)
Optional group project  
- 1 sub-grade up if you score (7/10), but most of us got only 6/10

My score:
HW 1 - 20/20
HW 2 - 14.5/20
HW 3 - 19.5/20
HW 4 - 20/20
HW 5 - 14/20
Group project - 6/10
Mid Term - 41/60  (Mean 44.3)
Final Exam - 90/130 (Mean 88.8)
Final Grade: B-

I hate maths and I have no common sense in physics so I think this course grading is very good
reviews.comment_workload:
Only 5 HW (1-4 short questions) + group project (optional)

Those homework are not that difficult to understand and you can definitely find some answers on google search.

I usually take around 1 hour to finish the HW so I would say the workload is quite light.

reviews.author: stephanie1234
reviews.title: Quite good grade
reviews.comment_content: The content of this course is quite easy and even you skipped lessons, you can still understand the stuffs from the powerpoints. The questions in midterm are almost the same or similar to the questions on the tutorial notes and homework. The midterm is super easy, full marks is 60 and 66 people got full marks while the mean is 56. For the final, the content is cumulative, and you have to understand the concepts more, not purely doing exercise is enough.
reviews.comment_teaching: The tutorials held by the TA are more useful.

However, you need to attend the tutorials as they cover important concepts that you will need to know for completing the homework. The TA will explain some key concepts in the lecture notes including some formulas and theories.

Homework x 5 10%
Midterm 30 MCs 45%
Final 35 MCs 45%

One optional project (Complete a slide with around 10 pages about one recent technology. Two people in a group)
If you get 8/10 or above, your final grade will be one subgrade up.

I got around 91% and scored an A which was pretty good.
A-'s cutoff was around 85%
reviews.comment_workload:
Only five homework throughout the semester and no attendance for lectures and tutorials. You can watch the zoom recordings before you do the homework and it won't take much time to complete the homework.

Midterm and Final were quite easy, I just went through all the lecture and tutorial notes a few days before. However, they were close book exam, which means you can't use any cheat sheet to help you for the exams.

reviews.author: aaronic92351
reviews.title: Light Workload, Transparent Grading
reviews.comment_content:
Contents are the same as previous semesters.
Chapter 1: Intro to Signals and Systems
Chapter 2: Digital Systems and Binary Logic
Chapter 3: Digitization
Chapter 4: Coding of Digital Information
Chapter 5: Wireless Communications
Chapter 6: Computer Networks and the Internet

As a business student with no prior knowledge in physics and electronics, it is still rather easy to understand the content. I did learnt more about signals and systems and computer network in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For this semester, mixed mode teaching was adopted for the course, which means you can either choose to attend lectures and tutorials in F2F or in zoom.

Prof is knowledgeable and passionate in the area of electronics. He mainly follows the ppt slides for teaching, with some additional handwritten graphs to explain the contents in a more detailed manner. It's 9am class so not many people actually attend the lectures.

Tang Tang, the TA, explains important concepts during tutorial sessions. He would also go over some examples, and make sure everyone understands before moving on. You can also ask him questions after the tutorials if you're shy.
He also held paper checking sessions after midterm and final exams, and i loved the transparency!
reviews.comment_grading:
Simple and Transparent Grading:
5 Homeworks â€“ 10%
Midterm (30 MCQs) â€“ 35%
Final (35 MCQs) â€“ 55%
Optional project: Two people one group, 8/10 or above --> one sub-grade up for your final grade

My scores:
HW1: 19.5/20 (mean: 18.72)
HW2: 20/20 (mean: 18.69)
HW3: 20/20 (mean: 17.99)
HW4: 20/20 (mean: 16.38)
HW5: 20/20 (mean: 16.61)
Midterm: 26/30 (mean: 22, sd: 4.94)
Final: 34/35 (mean: 25.6, sd: 5.89)
Optional project: Didn't do, personally think not worth it

Grade: A+
(didn't expect this, first cc A+! guessed i barely passed the cutoff)
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload, given that you attend lectures.
Since I had no prior knowledge on the contents, I attended every lecture and tutorial to keep up with the pace and make sure I understand the concepts. This can also avoid me reviewing everything right before the exams.

HWs can be finished in 2 hours.
For midterm and final, if you have no prior background like me, make sure to do practice with the tutorial examples and HWs. (I started revision 3 days before the exams.)
Recite some of the hard facts as well, esp. for final exam since there will be some questions on hard knowledge.

reviews.author: hime
reviews.title: Fair
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 - Introduction to Signals
Chapter 2 - Foundation of Digital Systems Binary Number Logic
Chapter 3 - Digitization From Signals to Digital Information
Chapter 4 - Introduction to Source Coding
Chapter 5 - Wireless Communications
Chapter 6 - Networks

As far as I know, some topics are covered in EE and MAE, so you can expect there are quite a number of students who have been already familiar with the content.

The content itself is quite interesting though in my opinion. It also sticks to our daily lives, so you should be able to at least learn something useful through this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor teaching is quite boring so I seldom went to her lectures. Lecture videos are provided so it should be not a big deal even you cannot catch up with the progress.

The tutorial is good. The TA explained stuff clearly and he is also willing to answer your questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 10%
Midterm 35%
Final 55%

There is also a optional group project which can raise a sub-grade if you score 7 or above out of 10, but I don't think you need this to boost your grade unless you are really free. Study for the midterm and final is much more meaningful.

Whether the grading is good really depends on your background and expectation. There would normally be three outcomes:

i) If you are an EE student (or MAE), the grading is very GOOD because you should be familiar with most of the content. You can easily score high marks with little effort. There are also many business students whom you can really shit on in the course.

ii) If you have no pre-requisite knowledge and only expect a fair grading (B-range or A-) with a fair amount of effort, the grading is kind of good to you. The content itself is not hard to understand, and the B-range of this course is also wide.

iii) If you have no pre-requisite knowledge and expect a good grade (A or above) from this course, then the grading is BAD to you. I am sure that it is almost impossible for you to beat the year 4 engineering students in the exams due to very limited time. Of course if you are a genius then you can ignore this.

P.S. The cut-off of A is around 88.x% for this semester.
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload.

Aside from the midterm and final, there are only 5 homework sets in total and all of them can be finished within 30 minutes.

Sure you can increase your own workload by doing the optional project, but again I don't really recommend to do it.

reviews.author: ma456
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 - Introduction to Signals

Instead, I focused my attention on studying the tutorial notes, since they cover all the essential concepts and provide numerous example questions and solutions. The tutorial notes are important.

Midterm and final only mc, the questions are not difficult, only involve some simple calculation

reviews.author: non
reviews.title: Easy contents, but lecture notes are not well-organized. Generally good grading, but challenging to get A+
reviews.comment_content:
The knowledge taught in this course is very basic. No complicated math and physics are involved. I'd like to particularly make some comments on the lecture notes.

The organization and structure of the course materials are a bit chaotic. For example, there are 3 topics A, B, and C. The arrangement could be like A+B (intro, but ambiguous) C (detailed) A (repeated) B (clarified) A+B (repeated) A (repeated) A (detailed) . Yes, proper times of repetition help students enhance their memory, but in the case of this course:
1. The same topic is scattered across different chapters, and the intervals between them can be quite distant.
2. The level of detail regarding a particular topic does not consistently increase or decrease, but rather fluctuates irregularly.
3. Some important topics suddenly appear without being defined (e.g., SNR_dB, only stated in the "Formulae that will be provided in the exam"), while others are abruptly cut off without further elaboration.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The quality of the lecture notes is mentioned in the content section. The teaching style is mentioned in the workload section.

Besides, the Prof. speaks fluent English and shows his proficiency in his teaching. With those information mentioned in other sections, I'd like to give it a B.
reviews.comment_grading:
A humorous thing during the final exam: The instructor emphasized the importance of carefully reading the instructions on the cover page, but one instruction stated "No name and SID on the MC sheet (0 marks)!!!", which is ambiguous and shocked me for quite a while LOL. (If I remember correctly, another reminder regarding the consequences of not filling in the version on the MC sheet is phrased in a different and clear manner such that this one looks totally the opposite)


Given the relatively straightforward nature of this course, the exams are likely to include highly specific and factual questions. These questions will play a significant role in determining whether you achieve an acceptable or satisfactory grade. However, it is important to note that your comprehension of the concepts will determine the baseline of your overall score.

Me and my friend:
- mid 28/30 + final 31/35 + only lost few marks in hw + no project bonus -> A
- mid 27/30 + final 33/35 + the same -> A+
(and you can refer to postexamples's review below, whose scores are very close to us)
reviews.comment_workload:
The homework wordload is very low: 1. the problem coverage is not wide. 2. the number of problems is small. 3. problems are easy.

If you want to gain a bonus from the project, you really need to be innovative and devoted. Our groups summarize a topic into a PPT, with appropriate math formulae and illustrations (but no pretty design, don't know if it matters), but result in a low score.

Again, though the content is straightforward, it is expected that you invest more time in digesting the material (as opposed to the knowledge) itself. (Disclaimer: I think the pace of the live lectures is too slow, and the prof sometimes includes supplementary but less significant information so I skipped them. I'm unsure if attending the lectures would be more efficient in terms of learning.)

So I'd like to give it a B (maybe between B and A)

reviews.author: Patrick Yuen
reviews.comment_content:
Total 6 Chapters:
Chapter 1 - Introduction to Signals
Chapter 2 - Foundation of Digital Systems Binary Number Logic
Chapter 3 - Digitization From Signals to Digital Information
Chapter 4 - Introduction to Source Coding
Chapter 5 - Wireless Communications

Contents are quite interesting and straight forward. For those who don't have science/Math background, you can handle the materials easily imo.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Yuan and Mr. Jie are nice guys. They add different real-life examples to explain the concepts, instead of reading out loud the content of lecture slides. They are also willing to answer the questions you raised.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 10%
Midterm 35%
Final 55%
Plus an optional project
reviews.comment_workload:
There will be 5 homework. All are not difficult and pretty straight-forward. 1-2 hours of time can complete one but you are given 1-2 weeks to finish.
For Midterm, pay attention to the examples they mentioned on the lessons, understand the concepts of each chapter and redo the assignment before the test should be enough. No need to study the materials outside the lecture.

reviews.author: ZC
reviews.comment_content:
Topic 1: Introduction to Signals
Topic 2: Foundation of Digital Systems and Binary Number Logic
Topic 3: Digitization From Signals to Digital Information
Topic 4: Introduction to Source Coding
Topic 5: Wireless Communications
Topic 6: Networks

Content before midterm is easier (i.e. Topic 1-3), but it got more complicated after midterm.
reviews.comment_teaching: All lectures are recorded, so it is not necessary to attend live lectures. And if you only care about how to do the exams and homeworks, just go to the tutorials, I don't think the lectures actually help unless you are really interested in the topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework (2% x 5) -- 10%
Midterm Exam -- 45%
Final Exam -- 45%
Project (Optional) -- 2 people in a group, and you can get one subgrade up if you get 8/10 or more

Homework 1 -- 19/20
Homework 2 -- 20/20
Homework 3 -- 20/20
Homework 4 -- 19.5/20
Homework 5 -- 19/20
Midterm -- 26/30 (Mean = 24.38)
Final -- 30/35 (Mean = 23.2)
Project -- did the project and got 8/10

Final grade: A+
(I think I originally got A but have one subgrade up because of the project so it becomes A+)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is really light if you don't do the optional project, the project did took me quite some time as you need to put in as much information as you can in the powerpoint to get more than 8 marks. Homeworks are simple as similar questions are covered during the tutorials. Midterm is easier than the final, although the professor said that the final covers all topics, basically only topics after midterm were tested, maybe just one or two questions on topics before midterm. No need to worry too much even you are not from engineering school, this course is fairly easy to handle (from a SBM student's point of view).

reviews.author: ReallyYum
reviews.title: Some Tips and Tricks on scoring an A
reviews.comment_content: As content has been discussed in great detail by other reviewers. I will not be repeating what the content of this class is.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Being honest here. The professor is simply paraphrasing what is being printed on the lecture notes so there isn't much of a need to attend the lectures.

However, tutorials are a MUST for you to attend if you want to get a good mark in the exam / full mark in the assignment as the TA will explain how exactly to work on questions that will either appear in the midterm and the final.
reviews.comment_grading:
For my particular case, I did not score high enough on my optional project. But there is a tip I could share from reading ppts of those who scored high:
Detail is key. If you are from SBM, try not to use the business mindset that you have to make it pretty or something. Instead, try to fill in as much information as you can since the professor will only be reading your PPT and you need to make sure you show that you have a good understanding of the topic.

Can't necessarily remember my mark. But I was above 0.85 sd in midterm. Got around 95% for my assignment.

Final Grade : A
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is rather light. If you are stuck on assignments. You could refer to the tutorials as they just changed the numerics. The principle is the same.

For both midterm and final. I just started studying the night before as both of them are heavily dependent on doing calculations. If you know how to do it, you are good to go.

For the finals, however, I would advise you to go over the concepts taught in class as they will appear in some of the MCs. That could be a crucial factor if you want to get a good grade.

Speed is also important as well, while the questions might be easy. It is more about quantity than quality. Midterm has only around 50 mins, so you need to be quick. So is the final. Good Luck. :)

reviews.comment_content: The content is quite easy. You do not need to attend the lecture. You just need to attend the tutorial if just aim for B range. Midterm is similar with the tutorial notes but final is related to both the lecture and tutorial. This is important.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture is quite boring. However, tutorial is quite interesting as it is much more precise and the tutor Ricky is also humorous and funny.

My midterm is 1sd higher than mean and my final is 2sd lower than mean lmao. And I got C
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is small. I put 20% effort(compare with other common core) still got C range

reviews.author: phcheungac
reviews.title: Easy course
reviews.comment_content:
There are 6 chapters in total:
Chapter 1 Introduction to Signals
Chapter 2 - Foundation of Digital Systems Binary Number Logic
Chapter 3 - Digitization From Signals to Digital Information
Chapter 4 - Introduction to Source Coding
Chapter 5 - Wireless Communications
Chapter 6 - Networks
Midterm will cover the first 3 chapters. Final is cumulative, by mainly the material in chapters 4 to 6 will be tested.
The content is easy to understand for everyone, so the science/ engineering students do not have much advantages in it, except they can take less time on revision if they have learnt the concept already.
The exams are intense in terms of the testing time. You will find it bit rush to finish the whole exam paper, so if you are prepared for answering fast and finish it on time, you are better than the majority of the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is straightforward, concepts are clear, and the difficulty suits as the introductory 1000-level course. Therefore, it is not likely for students to struggle in learning if they put effort.
There is no participation mark, and the lecture videos are provided, so it is up to you to attend the lecture or not. If you are exam-oriented, just attending tutorial maybe fine enough. The TA also responds fast via email.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is good.
You can do an optional group project, which you can get 1 sub-grade up for getting 7/10. Although it is difficult to attain 7/10 (like the mean is 2.2/10), you may find it easier to put as much as information as you can in the project to show your knowledge. You and your partner are not necessarily science/ engineering students as the groups with high scores are from business school.
Exam is easy, you will have positive return if you revise. I got 1 score above the mean in midterm, and I got 1 SD above in final, I got an A- at last.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is very light. Only 5 assignments are compulsory, which are very easy if you have attended the tutorial session. Basically you will find the similar pattern in the tutorial notes.
The group project is optional, so you can choose not to do it if you do not have enough time, even you have registered to do the project. There is no penalty for not submitting the project.

Some advantage if you have study phy in DSE & huge advantage if you have study elec1200/2100 before.

Signal : fundamental frequency, period, sound signal (pitch, timbre, loudness), harmonics, modulation
Logic gate, bit/bytes & binary representation.
Digitization : sampling & quantization, Nyquist Theorem, information capacity, entropy
Source coding : lossy/lossless compression, fixed-length code, variable-length code, prefix code, huffman code
Channel coding : error detection/correction, parity check, repetition code, 2d parity code, channel capacity
Wireless communication : base station, cell, frequency reuse, hand-off, FDMA, TDMA, CDMA
Network : components in networks, circuit switching, packet switching, CDN, P2P

Homework 4: 11/20
Homework 5: 16/20
Final Grade: C+
If you don't want to be like me, then work your ass off as lots of people will work hard and get high grades in this course
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair workload
Most of the assignments have 3 questions with a few subparts within them.
Only the first assignment requires the use of Excel.
if the question does not require steps, you don't need to provide the steps. You only need to write the answer with the correct units.
For the questions requiring steps, write down every step or else you lose all the marks even if you have the right answer.

reviews.author: wklee

reviews.comment_content:
Other student has mentioned so i dont write here.

The whole course just teach you something basic and even a secondary school student can understand what this course is teaching.
reviews.comment_teaching: I skip all lesson so can tell nothing. But the professor will send us back the notes that he had written in the lecture, so I guess his teaching should be not bad?
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite good
The assessment is based on 5 HW and 1 midterm and 1 final. For HW almost all student can get full marks as long as you have attended the tutorial notes.
For midterm it is quite easy, but at the same time many people get high marks, therefore you have to be careful.
There are also an optional group project but i personally dont suggest working on it as there are only a small proportion of student who can get 8 marks or above. (the upper quartile is 5 marks). Moreover the deadline of the project is on 31/10. (which may collide with your midterm) Therefore to reduce the workload and spare more time for revision, you better skip this project.
reviews.comment_workload:
Relatively light.
For me I just read the tutorial notes and its enough for me to complete the HW. Of course in midterm you also have to make revision on the lecture notes,

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: Pretty good
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 - Introduction to Signals
Chapter 2 - Foundation of Digital Systems Binary Number Logic
Chapter 3 - Digitization From Signals to Digital Information
Chapter 4 - Introduction to Source Coding
Chapter 5 - Wireless Communications
Chapter 6 - Networks

Decently interesting, all very basic and there's not a lot of math involved. If you have taken ELEC1200, you would already have a pretty good understanding of the first 4 chapters (Quite unfair that students are allowed to take this course after ELEC1200), a quick note that for the last 2 chapters, you need to memorize a lot and also spend some time understanding the various multiple access protocols.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures: Just repeating what's on the powerpoint, not worth attending, skipped after 2-3 classes.

Tutorial: Also just repeating what's on the powerpoint (better than the lectures though), however it is important that you at least review the tutorial notes since they help a lot in answering questions for the assignments AND the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
5 Assignments (10%, 2% each): 3-4 questions per assignment, pretty basic stuff, averages are high, ranging from 16/20 to 18/20.

Midterm (35%): 50 minutes, 30 MCQs, closed book and closed notes, questions are very simple, however some memorization is required, averages are very high. (23/30)

Final (55%): 50 minutes, 35 MCQs, closed book and closed notes, covering all materials. Again questions are very simple, but even more memorization is needed as the last 2 chapters are quite dense. Averages are also very high. (26/35)

Optional group project: 2 people per group, making a presentation related to information technology, if you get a score of 8/10 or higher, your grade will be one sub-grade higher, otherwise you get nothing.

My score: Mean for everything, did not do the group project, B, quite good!
reviews.comment_workload:
Typical CC workload.

Since there's only 3-4 questions per assignment, answering them would not take a lot of time. For the exams, memorizing the powerpoints is the only thing you need to do, you should also do the past papers, which are given by the course.

The first few chapters were not difficult and easy to understanding. HKDSE physics covered some of the topics. As a SBM student with HKDSE physics background, the difficulty is moderate. reviews.comment_teaching:
Due to the pandemic, this semester are all live time online classes. We can review the lecture and tutorial videos online.

Personally, I think there is no need to go to lecture. Miss Lau is a nice professor, but she talks really slowly, and the lecture is very boring. It is more effective to review the lecture video in 1.5x pace.

Raymundo, the TA, is very helpful. The tutorial is faster and more precise, compared to the lecture. He is so nice and helpful that he can answer the questions immediately.

I give a D to Miss Lau's teaching and a B to Raymundo's teaching. So, I take a C in average.
reviews.comment_grading:

50 mins for 30 questions in midterm. The time is far more than enough. Lots of people early leave. As I said, if you understand the hw and lecture materials, it's totally fine for midterm. Questions are straight forward.

reviews.author: HelloUST
reviews.title: Easy elective course for ELEC / CPEG students
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1: Signals and Systems
Chapter 2: Digital Systems
Chapter 3: Digitization
Chapter 4: Coding of Digital Information
Chapter 5: Communications
Chapter 6: The Internet

Most of the materials have been taught in elec1200 and other elec courses so if you are an elec/cpeg student, you won't learn much.

If you are not an elec/cpeg student, the contents are very interesting and highly relevant to the "smart" world we live in so I highly encourage you take the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Great instructor overall. He tries his best to explain the concepts in layman terms. The course itself is not too technical but he makes  effort in trying to make sure that every student from different backgrounds can have a good understanding of the course content. His teaching pace is a little slow but other than that I would say he was very well prepared and a good instructor overall.
reviews.comment_grading:
55% final exam
35% midterm exam
10% homework

The course itself is pretty easy but there are like a few hundred students taking this course. Because the school can't have like 50 ELEC students getting full marks, they decided to make the exam a time-attack. Especially for the mid term exams, there were like 17pages of questions in a 50 min exam. I got really nervous due to the overwhelming amount of questions and ended up making stupid mistakes. For example, there's a lot of trick questions such as having bits and bytes mixed up (one question might have Kb and another might have KB). I guess it was their way of preventing full marks but it's really not an exam to test what you learned. It's just an exam to distribute students to a smooth bell curve.

There is an optional project you can do to receive extra grade (from A- to A, c+ to b-). However the professor told us that it's gonna be quite competitive to get that extra grade. I didn't do it because I don't it's worth the effort and time.
reviews.comment_workload: Other than the exams, you only have 5 homework. They are all quite easy and can be solved in less than 30 minutes. The perfect elective course for final elec/cpeg students who will be busy doing their FYPs.

reviews.author: ç‡ƒç‡’ä¸­çš„GPA
reviews.title: A better choice for fulfilling SSC-S&T requirement than PHYS1003/LIFS1030 if you are good at Mathematics
reviews.comment_content:
There are 6 chapters:

Chapter 1 - Introduction to Signals
Chapter 2 - Foundation of Digital Systems Binary Number Logic
Chapter 3 - Digitization From Signals to Digital Information
Chapter 4 - Introduction to Source Coding
Chapter 5 - Wireless Communications
Chapter 6 - Networks

Midterm exam covers chapters 1-3.
Final exam is cumulative, which covers all 6 chapters.

This course involves some secondary school level mathematics (binary numbers, logarithm, probability, etc.). The mathematics is not too difficult as long as your mathematics is not too bad. The tutorials will help you a lot in this course, including the mathematics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures: Prof. Sin explains the concepts quite clearly.
Tutorials: Ricky (TA) will highlight the important things you have to know in this course. He will also point out some common misconceptions by students. If you have any questions about your homework, feel free to ask him. He is willing to answer your questions patiently. Attending all tutorials is highly recommended, although there is no attendance-taking.
reviews.comment_grading:
[Since the Canvas page for this course was closed one day after the final exam paper checking, the statistics below may not be finalized and accurate.]

10% Homework (5 homework assignments, 2% each):
HW 1: 20/20 (mean: 18.3)
HW 2: 20/20 (mean: 18.2)
HW 3: 20/20 (mean: 17.5)
HW 4: 20/20 (mean: 16)
HW 5: 19.5/20 (mean: 16.6)


35% Midterm Exam (50 minutes):
Part I: 10 MCQs x 2 marks each = 20 marks (mean: 14.2)
Part II: 5 Short Questions x 8 marks each = 40 marks (mean: 31.6)
Total: 60 marks (mean: 45.9, SD: 9.43)

My score: 55.75/60 (+1.04 SD)


55% Final Exam (2 hours):
Part I: 29 MCQs x 2 marks each = 58 marks (mean: 40.8)
Part II: 6 Short Questions x 12 marks each = 72 marks (mean: 55.4)
Total: 130 marks (mean: 96.2, SD not announced)

My score: 116.5/130 (My guess: ~1 SD above mean, based on past statistics)


Overall: 91.76%
Grade: A+

I guess the cut-off for A+ is around 90%. The grading is quite lenient.
reviews.comment_workload:
The homework questions are very similar to the examples in tutorial notes, so you don't have to spend too much time on homework.

Past exam papers are provided. Some formulas and equations will also be provided during exams.

If your target is B range, familiarizing yourself with the tutorial notes, homework and past papers is enough.

If your target is A range, read the lecture notes as well (for answering the conceptual MCQs in final exam).

Time management is extremely important in both exams. Don't struggle on the questions that you are not familiar with.

For the midterm exam, you may not have enough time to finish the paper. You may finish the short questions first because the short questions are easier, more straightforward and more similar to homework/tutorial notes than the MCQs. The MCQs are quite tricky - beware of what the questions are asking you about!

For the final exam, invest in the MCQs as they are easier than the short questions. Some questions are conceptual. Going through the past final exam paper once will help, as some MCQs are similar to those in the past paper. If you have enough time, read the lecture notes (especially chapter 5 & 6) as well. The short questions are quite challenging. (I scored 58/58 in MCQs and 58.5/72 in short questions. You can see that the MCQs helped me a lot in scoring high in the final exam.)

reviews.author: Alanx
reviews.title: Super Good Grade
reviews.comment_content:
Ch1 modulation & filter
Ch2 binary number & logic
Ch3 digitalization
Ch4 information coding method
Ch5 signal transmission method (1G 2G 3G 4G)
Ch6 information transmission via network

If you are CS, you should know logic and huffman coding (seems not covered every semester)
If you are CPEG or ELEC, you should know logic and modulation and blablabla (not too sure)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Generally useless. Prof just reading PPT.
Tutorial might be more useful as different questions type in the exam will be discussed.
Some conceptual notes other than calculation in tutorial are also useful if you really don't even wanna read the long lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Super good grade.
The course information is deleted right after the grade was released so I cannot remember the allocation of each part and the exact score and mean.
Assignment: almost full
Midterm: ~92% (mean ~75%)
Final: ~88% (mean ~73%)
Optional project: no bonus (around half of the teams got bonus, add one sub-grade)
Overall: A+
I thought I cannot get A+ since I failed to get bonus with the optional project, but turns out with the midterm and final not even closed to full can still get A+ :)

BTW the midterm and final paper is super super long for this semester so even you are confident, don't do it too slow especially when you may need to draw lots of graphs in the midterm exam. The amount of questions in sample papers are not true!
reviews.comment_workload: 5 easy HW and 1 optional project (only PPT, need to present in LT if you are the most excellent group).

reviews.comment_teaching:
It has lecture videos!
The topics before midterms are understandable.
However, after midterm, the topics are a bit difficult to understand and I was already left behind in class and went to lecture video.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments (per 2week), Midterm, Final, Optional Project
Bad grade!!!
Midterm is not hard as questions and calculations are similar to those in assignments. However, you wont have enough time to finish your midterm since the time is really limited.
Tutorials are useful since the TA will teach you the calculations.
My midterm got below 1sd and got mean in final
Assignments all full marks and turn out C+
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair workload,
Assignments are not too demanding
Better manage your time in midterm and memorize in final

reviews.author: lili036
reviews.comment_content:
There are 6 chapters
Chapter 1 Introduction to signals
Chapter 2 Foundation of Digital Systems Binary Number logic
Chapter 3 Digitization from signals to digital information
Chapter 4 Introduction to source coding
Chapter 5 Wireless communication
Chapter 6 Networks

The lectures materials are not too much and easy to understand
You must read tutorial notes or attend tutorials in order to understand the concepts cause most homework follows tutorials as well as midterm and final.
There is an optional projects, you can skip it
reviews.comment_teaching:
I only attended the lectures for around 3-4 times cause there will be lectures video posted on canvas.
Sometimes I dont really understand what the professor said cause he seems to make the concept more difficult to understand, so I just skipped the lecture video as well.
Tang tang is a little bit better, but he seems not really prepared tutorials before class. sometimes he will get lost during the tutorial.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 10%
Midterm 35%
Final 55%

The grading is fair
Everyone got almost full marks in homework, or one or two careless mistake is fine
Midterm is quite easy, only 50 mins to finish the paper, so you need to rush and most people canâ€™t finish it. but the mean is really high, if you got some careless mistakes, you will absolutely below mean
Final have two hours, and the questions are still very easy, mean is really high.
I think the average grading should be B- to B
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework is not really hard but some needs time to do it
Most of the questions are just mentioned in the tutorials, just follow the tutor notes you will know how to do it
If you skip the project, then the workload is much lesser

reviews.author: Maggie Tong
reviews.comment_content: The content is basically manageable and straight- forward. A total of six chapters are taught in this semester, ranging from the introduction of signals and systems to source coding.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cupid, who is the teaching assistant, is very patient and kind. She is responsible for the teaching of the tutorials. If you find any difficulties, don't hesitate to ask her both after the lecture and tutorials.
The professor speaks in monotone and the lecture notes sometimes have too many demonstrations about the sound, which I think is not necessary to attend the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not really good. Since the mean of both midterm and final are both quite high, more than 50% of the full marks.
Homework 10%
Midterm 35%
Final 55%
You can also choose to do an optional group project. 2 students in a group to finish both a presentation and report. If your project score is 7 or above (full mark is 10), your grade will be one sub-grade up. However, getting a 7 is very difficult, not many students chose to do it.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 Assignments
1 midterm
1 final
The workload is fair.

reviews.title: Good grade course to learn technology with real life examples
reviews.comment_content: The content is useful which is closely related to the technology we met in daily lives. Examples provided in the lectures are easy to understand and follow
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecturer taught with passions. You can link the content with daily lives examples. However, it takes time to understand the calcuiation and mecahnism behind all the technologies. Attending tutorials would be userful. However, most of the tutors would prefer to write all the answers on whiteboard without guiding students who were in doubt. The tutors are general approachable after tutorials to give special guidance to those who can't follow in class. Strong support network is shown.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grade. You could score high if you try to memorise the calculation steps to arrive at the answers.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite fair. It would become more heavy-loaded when you decided to pursue bonus points by taking the group project. However, it comes into view that the group project wasn't determining your final grade but just a add-on bonus. You can still score high, like A+, if you can't get bonus point from the group project.

reviews.author: cotton
reviews.comment_content: Very basic sound wave stuffs and some calculations of bits and bytes? No background on physics or calculus  is required.
reviews.comment_teaching: Boring. As there are lecture videos and the lecture notes are easy to understand, attending lectures is optional I think. Tutorials are important as they talks about the homework questions. You can get full marks in homework if you follow well in the tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
About 50% of the class got full marks in midterm. There are more long questions in final exam but the mean was still high.

You can get a sub grade bonus if you choose to do the optional project and overall get 7/10 marks (5 marks for a PPT and 5 marks for a report) for it. I have done the project but cannot got the bonus as I only got few marks in the report part. Only 10 out of 70 groups got >3.5 marks in the report part. If you choose to do the project, grab more marks in the PPT part.

I got full marks in midterm, marks above ~1 sd in final and no project bonus and finally got A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Easy homework for every two weeks.

reviews.author: Phoebe
reviews.title: ELEC 1010
reviews.comment_content: Easy to understand. Midterm is rather easy, similar to homework exercises.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Attendance is not taken. Teaching is clear. Most of the things taught can be found in the powerpoint slides.
Tutorial is useful because it will talk about some questions which are similar to the assignments. So if you do not know how to do the assignment, you can attend the tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
55% final,
35% midterm,
10% homework,
one optional term project (one sub grade up if got above 7/10)

Good grade. But the mean for the midterm and final will be quite high, especially for midterm. Many students who have ELEC background can get full marks.
For the optional term project, you will need to write 1000 words report and do a powerpoint. Some of the best groups are required to do presentation during tutorials or class. But it is rather hard to get above 7/10 in the project.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload. Only 5 assignments. (Each assignment can finish within 20 minutes). Strongly advised to go to tutorials if you do not know how to do.

reviews.author: Tony Li
reviews.title: ELEC1010
reviews.comment_content: Basic stuff about signalling, not that difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: Actually, I did not attend much classes, so I was not that sure whether the teaching is good or not.
reviews.comment_grading:
55% final,
35% midterm,
10% homework,
one optional term project (one sub grade up if got above 7/10)

I think the grading is very good. I got full marks in midterm and rated as 35% in the final exam, but I still got an A. I heard that since many students got high marks in the exam, so they adjusted the grading with reference to the past few year. If I could do the project better, I thought the grade will be much better.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not that much. Since the lecture notes were nicely organized, I just skipped most of the classes and studied lecture notes in the study break.

reviews.author: Olivia:)
reviews.comment_content: This general-education course introduces the basics of electronic and information technology and their applications to daily-life consumer electronics and communication devices. Contents include the representation of signals in the time and frequency domains; digitization of information; coding for data compression and error protection; transmission of signals; cellular mobile phones and wireless communications; and the Internet. It is expected that through studying these technologies and how they address the problems encountered in the information technology area, students will also grasp the skills in solving problems with engineering approach and spirit and appreciate how these technologies impact the society
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof was nice. TA was very helpful and more exam-orientated.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade was good. It was not hard to get an A.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly assignments, which were not very hard tho.

reviews.comment_grading: Good grade if you are able to complete all laboratory work and the final project of moving your robot on a track. Moreover, do not miss any pop up quiz and hence you will be able to get a good grade together with your partner.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fairly light if you are able to finish all the work required in laboratory, and a little bit of thinking is needed for the final part of the project.

reviews.comment_grading:
I did not review before midterm or final, but somehow I got slightly above median in both midterm and final.
In the final exam, I could not understand a single word for about 10 questions because I had not even read the slides once, but still got a result above median. WOW.
This leads to a B+, EXTREMELY good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 assignments, one midterm, one final.
In total, I spent about 10 hours on this course, including 50 minutes for midterm and 50 minutes for final.
If you are an EE student and you just want to fulfill the CC requirement without wasting much time, just come.

Content is the same every semester.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ok teaching. Prof just reads lecture ppts. You can skip the lectures and self study with the ppt. Tutorials are useful to understand the problem sets.

reviews.comment_workload: Very low workload. Just do the problem set assignments. There is an optional group project done in pairs before midterm exam to boost one sub grade if scored above 8/10. Apparently it is hard to get above 8.

reviews.author: Oil Rabbit
reviews.title: ELEC1100
reviews.comment_content: The content is very easy. Just do some revision before exams then you can get a high score.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teach is ok. Just follow PDF to study.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is bad. Mostly depends on the final project. Since it is zoom in 2020-2021 Spring semester so they help you download your code to the car and demo for you. But if you fail to run the whole path then you must get a bad grade for this course.

It has few labs and some IPRS quizzes which are very easy. Midterm exam is also easy.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is low. Just finish the lab and the project code which is very easy.
